messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: Hi. While I have not seen it I understand - I hope I have this right!! - that Richard Suran of the So. Cal. club wrote a Masters thesis on the Goto. That
messages.messageBody:
Hi.
While I have not seen it I understand - I hope I have this right!! - that
Richard Suran of the So. Cal. club wrote a Masters thesis on the Goto.
That should make very intersting reading.

Arnold Frenzel
afrenzel@...

> Lucien,
>
> The best Goto book out there is Goto Book from NBTHK By: Fukushi Sensei
> Another good book is SWORD FITTINGS BY THE FAMILY OF GOTO 1440 - 1879 1994.
> Sano Art Museum, Nezu Institute of Fine Arts, Tokugawa Art Museum.
>
> I'm sure that there are other books on Goto fittings, but these two come to
> mind first.
>
> Lou

messages.subject: Re: goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: Hey thanks guys, Well, I guess study is what I ll have to do. Now to save up for that huge goto book. I saw one on Robert benson s site and also I think
messages.messageBody:
Hey thanks guys,
Well, I guess study is what I'll have to do. Now to save up for that
huge goto book. I saw one on Robert benson's site and also I think
Satcho's site. I look forward to digging in!
Does any museums have goto fittings in the US other than the Boston
museum?
Thanks, LB



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@u...>
wrote:
> Curran -

> Rick and Dan are both "as good as they come" and true "students" of
Goto works and of the sword. Rick is the treasurer of the newly formed
American branch of the NBTHK. Neither one participate on these
discussion/chat groups. I have not checked the NCJSC's web site in
awhile but it wouldn't surprise me to see some of these or some other
equally fine kodogu pictured there.
>
> Quality made photographs are great but to see this quality of work a
few inches from one's eyes, in the "flesh," is something else! This
brings to mind a really fine tsuba I once owned signed Natsuo. It was
good and Bob Haynes agreed, but also added that it would never "pass"
in Japan. A couple years later I was at the Boston MFA and for the
first time I saw a "real" Natsuo work and immediately, I recognized
that my wonderful tsuba simply did not at all have the quality that
radiated from that "real" Natsuo. Same with mainline Goto works. That
"quality" speaks for itself!
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: Curran - Rick and Dan are both as good as they come and true students of Goto works and of the sword. Rick is the treasurer of the newly formed American
messages.messageBody:
Curran -

Rick and Dan are both "as good as they come" and true "students" of Goto works and of the sword. Rick is the treasurer of the newly formed American branch of the NBTHK. Neither one participate on these discussion/chat groups. I have not checked the NCJSC's web site in awhile but it wouldn't surprise me to see some of these or some other equally fine kodogu pictured there.

Quality made photographs are great but to see this quality of work a few inches from one's eyes, in the "flesh," is something else! This brings to mind a really fine tsuba I once owned signed Natsuo. It was good and Bob Haynes agreed, but also added that it would never "pass" in Japan. A couple years later I was at the Boston MFA and for the first time I saw a "real" Natsuo work and immediately, I recognized that my wonderful tsuba simply did not at all have the quality that radiated from that "real" Natsuo. Same with mainline Goto works. That "quality" speaks for itself!

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, September 22, 2003 2:56 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study


Ron-

Actually I took some time to study it. So many
exceptional pieces in such a small space.

Don't know if it was Rick or Dan I spoke with, but
they were nice to me as I pondered the hypnotic depth
of blackness in some of the menuki. I wrote down the
fellow's name, hoping to correspond further and get
some computer images if there were any to be had and
cataloged. Unfortunately the name/address got lost in
the paper shuffle of travelling back to the east
coast.

If there are any images of that display available,
someone please let me know. Coloration was beautiful
and the designs so much more full than can be done
justice in the Goto books I've seen.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: Lucien The 17 Generations of Goto (Japanese text). the hard and softback editions are two different books, the hard cover is by Shimada and the soft cover is
messages.messageBody:
Lucien
The 17 Generations of Goto (Japanese text). the hard and softback editions
are two different books, the hard cover is by Shimada and the soft cover is
the Sano Museum catalogue, both are out of print but I have the Sano at
GBP50 plus post if anybody needs one.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: Lucien - I believe the NBTHK book by Fukushi Sensei is a very large volume that came out a year or so ago. If so--and I have a copy myself but have yet to
messages.messageBody:
Lucien -

I believe the NBTHK book by Fukushi Sensei is a very large volume that came out a year or so ago. If so--and I have a copy myself but have yet to really "get into it"--it is pricey and (I believe) out-of-print. The only book on Goto I had prior to this large work was the one titled: The 17 Generations of Goto (Japanese text). I have this in both hard cover and soft cover, I believe both being the same inside the covers. It seems very good but as always, so much is missed unless you can read Japanese.

Hopefully those who attended this year's San Francisco show saw the small but significant display of Goto fittings put on by Rick Mantigani and Dan Burns. Absolutely awesome kodogu! Unbelievable crisp and "minty" items of high, high quality makers! This display has been shown the last few years but I really wonder how many people stop to study the treasures displayed.

Some of these Goto fittings--and others--have been included as special inserts (high quality photos and printing) in the Northern California group's newsletter from time to time.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: JapaneseSwords@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, September 21, 2003 4:12 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] goto kodogu study


Lucien,

The best Goto book out there is Goto Book from NBTHK By: Fukushi Sensei
Another good book is SWORD FITTINGS BY THE FAMILY OF GOTO 1440 - 1879 1994.
Sano Art Museum, Nezu Institute of Fine Arts, Tokugawa Art Museum.

I'm sure that there are other books on Goto fittings, but these two come to
mind first.

Lou

messages.subject: goto kodogu study
messages.msgSnippet: I was told by Mr. Ron Hartman on Robert Coles forum that this group was for discussing Kodogu. 1) Who is considered to be the best goto master? 2) who in the
messages.messageBody:
I was told by Mr. Ron Hartman on Robert Coles forum that this
group was for discussing Kodogu.
1) Who is considered to be the best goto master?
2) who in the goto ke had the least talent?
3) You hardly ever see Yujo's work except in museums. Are there any
books available that we could see such work?
4)What's the highest rating a goto master's work has gone to?
Anyone out there willing to show some early goto stuff in their
collection?
Regards, Lucien
PS, Are there any dream n' drool Goto books out there with lots of
pics?
